text:
This girls come from my hometown Amersfoort. Today I saw a tv episode about Lisanne Vroon. What really moved me was that her parents an brother said that they are still glad that Lisanne went to Panama, that she did what she wanted to do. 
In the documentary her brother and a the guide, who alarmed the authorities, followed the same path as the girls did. Everywhere aside the path are warning signs that it can be very slippery. These signs were placed after the accident. So I think they didn‚Äôt wander of the trail but slides from the path, where one of the girls broke her foot.
There is one mystery however. The original trail is to the top. Then you go back. The girls didn‚Äôt go back, they went on. But somehow I can understand that. Lisanne played volleyball on a heigh level, so her condition was ok. Then it‚Äôs easy to think ‚Äúlet‚Äôs go a little further‚Äù. 
All in all she had well spent time in Panama. So I understand the feelings of the family. They want to celebrate her life, not her death.

text:
Other youtube videos talk about a deleted photo from the camera that can't be retrieved. Photo number 509 that was between the last daytime photos and the night photos taken days later. It couldn't be retrieved because it looked like someone downloaded that photo from the camera to another computer. Also looking at the daytime photos you see a change in the mood and terrain. At first the photos show both girls on the high ground and looking happy. Then it changes to showing them on low ground going deeper into the jungle and only one of the girls is in the pictures and she doesn't look happy.

The first cellphone call was made only a couple of hours after the last day photo 508 was taken. They ran into a third party out there and may have got a picture of them (missing 509) and managed to get away. Unfortunately they were totally lost and grouped out the jungle for next next few days being chased and were caught again and killed. 

Those 77 attempts to get into the iphone were made by the third party, probably looking to see if it had any photos in it. I believe the night photos were taken to make it look like the girls got lost and one of them was hurt in a fall. The girls were long dead by then. The backpack was found in an area that was 12 hours away from where the girls were hiking. The backpack and its contends were dry and the camera and phones were in working order. Someone held on to them and then placed them in a spot to be found two months later because there is no way they would be in good condition after sitting in a jungle during the rainy season all this time. Plus the backpack  and the girls remains were found upstream.

They were murdered and the incompetent and crooked government declared that they got lost and died by accident so the tourist would keep on coming.

text:
I think you‚Äôre on the right track, Mike.

A couple of thoughts:
1. They might have been using the flash during the night as a last ditch effort hoping searchers or anyone might see it. The Panamanian jungle is simply pitch-black at night, so any light would would be anomalous & pique curiosity.

2. It does look like they fashioned some crude flags to - again - try to signal for help.

3. As for leaving the trail? I don‚Äôt find that mysterious at all! Young women, excited to be in such an exotic place, intelligent & educated, staying with locals who had surely imparted some knowledge of the area - it probably just didn‚Äôt seem like a big deal to explore a bit. They wouldn‚Äôt be the first tourists to underestimate how far off they wandered, either, & not be able to find their way back.

4. Perhaps the friend of the wounded girl refused to leave her alone to seek help. They were already very lost at that point, no doubt scared out of their minds. Perhaps the wound was quite severe. Bleeding in the jungles of mid-to-S. America would immediately attract all kinds of bugs, creepy-crawlies, and, um . . . other creatures. Also, infection would/could set in immediately in such an environment.

5. Doubtful they had much food or water with them. It would have been highly risky to partake of any local flora or water, too. If they had eaten anything in the environment, it could have led to serious illness, perhaps even hallucinations. Starving people will, however, eat anything. Not to discount whatever microbes would be in the stream water, either.

6. In my opinion, one or both died of injuries combined with dehydration & exposure. What a terrible way to die! My heart breaks for their families/friends. We might be living in a modern age of amazing technology, science, & medicine - but none of that makes us immune to little errors that can quickly snowball into tragedy. We‚Äôre still just walking, talking bags of bone & protoplasm at the end of the day.

I‚Äôm really impressed by your reporting, Mike (& I‚Äôm not easily impressed!) You look into stories on a deeper level & have more respect for facts than most on YouTube with similar channels. I‚Äôm also pleased that you‚Äôre okay with leaving things as they are - meaning unsolved, incomplete. That‚Äôs how reality works much of the time, unfortunately. So THANK YOU for for this most excellent channel! I enjoy it very much. Now I just have to remember to ‚Äòthumbs up‚Äô every video I watch!

text:
Once seeing this case here on Mike's channel, i became obsessed with this case devouring tens of not, close to 100 hours of research and imho, i think that the mystery regarding the backpack and the actual cause for the girls demise are two entirely separate incidences and are really connected nor related. 
I think it was either dropped accidentally or intentionally by the last girl to die. If it was the former, it was either running away from some preceived immediate danger such as a 4 legged predator (even worse, a 2 legged predator) with nefarious intentions towards her survival. The second possible reason  is that she dropped accidentally and no way to safely retrieve it. 
Now if she intentionally  abandoned it, she was trying to leave clues for the parties that would inevitably come searching for them although common sense would dictate that you leave one clue at a time instead of the whole kitnkaboodle making the backpack et al. The ominous reason for that would be that she was either in the midst of foul play or had reason enough to be anticipating its immenant arrival OR what seemsplausible to me, she had deteriorated to the point that she no longer had the strenght to carry it.
What i think occurred next is that a local came across the backpack and took it cos let's face it, who wouldn't take a brand new backpack they found in the middle of a jungle filled with things that someone above mentioned was worth more than what most of them earn in a year, even if it was only to try and find the original owners and return it. Upon realizing what was going on and who this backpack belonged to or the implications that it represented which made it impossible to profit from the items since it would make them suspect #1, they stayed low and then placed it where they knew it would be found with ease hence it's perfect condition. No body wants the authorities in their business which isbecome POI #1 which is objectionable for obvious reasons and it could also impact their operations if  they were involved with some sort of illegal activities in that area.
Now, exactly what killed these two young girls? Obviously i don't know but I'd be putting my üí∞ on them succumbing to their environment after a series of mishaps but readily agree that the chances for that not being the case is very much present for there are a few things that bother me about this case.

text:
In April of 2008 I hiked the trail up to the top of volcan Baru in the middle of the night by myself to watch the sunrise at the summit. I started at about 930/ 10pm and sunrise was around 6 am if I recall correctly. 

One thing that struck me while doing that hike was towards the end of the hike - near the summit - there is a scrambling section with some really steep drops on either side - some sections the ground is quite unstable as it is all loose dirt and loose stone. I remember thinking if I fell or slipped on this section I was for sure a goner.

It was a bit freaky on that trail at night alone.

text:
They were murdered. Nothing fits in this case. They never went far upstream, because the nightphoto with the 2 red plastic bags was made on the river with the bridge near the mirador. That means that the bones, the jeans and the bag must have floated UPSTREAM which is impossible. Then the bag was found 2 weeks later on a sandbank near the river. It must have floated upstream again and while being in the water, the camera and the mobile phone would have been destroyed. Furthermore the sunglasses are different from the ones the girls had. The girls were quite risk averse, because they started the same hike one day ago and stopped it due to nightfall - they knew where they were going.
Then within 2 months the bodies do not disintegrate that much. Without external force this is totally impossible, even in the jungle. One bone of kris was bleached and saturated with phosphor. The last photo before the nightphotos began, was deleted by computer and therefore not restorable. There were fingerprints found on the camera, but never evaluated !! Then they were girls with smartphones. No fotos, no messages, nothing for days they shall have been alife ?

This whole story is so full of things that don¬¥t fit together that i think they were kidnapped and killed. They were killed and all the "proofs" were made later to distract and let it look as if they just lost their way and got eaten by animals. What is even more frightening for me is that obviously the government of Panama seems to know more and hides it. Especially since the murder of Catherine Johannet in 2017 and the following investigation by FBI this became very clear.

I can just advice people not to go to latin and south america. Those countries are very dangerous and one human life doesn¬¥t count anything there. Search on the internet and you will find out that robberies and even murders of tourists take place everywhere there from Guatemala down to Argentina.

text:
I used to work with a medical examiner's office and, I have been to a few scenes like this..
Hey Mike!  Hope you read this.  There is a big inconsistently in the middle of this one that doesn't add up.
Forests of any kind, but most of all, jungles, are not kind to clothing...  So, over a few days, let alone the few weeks (was it?) It took for the shorts to be found they certainly shouldn't have appeared, "folded neatly on the opposite side of the trail from where the backpack was found..."  
This same backpack, containing the cellphones, that the lady swore, "wasn't there the day before", with no water or environmental damage?
(Mike, are those the actual photos of what was recovered?  The items are way too clean in more than one way.)
The cellphones, pack and bones all should have been found together.  The shorts should have been on or near the pelvic bone or in the backpack, (if, for some reason, she had taken them off).  Not several metres away and folded up neatly.  

My theory is that it is most likely a case where a local found the stuff and, not realizing the importance of it, kept it, washed it, but, when the news about  investigation into the disappearances came into the area, they realized what they had and figured they'd better return the gear.

 Or... the Panamanian government is covering up for a serial killer in their mountains rather than lose the tourist dollars.  
Or, the girls were trafficked.

I have been watching too many of these videos to be thinking those last two...
Keep safe.

text:
I used to live in Panama. The last thing two girls should ever do is hike solo there. I‚Äôve seen quite few tourist go home in a box or go missing. You got keep your head on a swivel there.

The thing most people don‚Äôt realize, is that there are a ton of little villages all over the jungle. Natives live in them, and to an untrained eyes you‚Äôd never find them. 

I remember one time a coworker of mine was jogging down a well traveled road through the jungle. Out of the blue this Indian guy pops out of the jungle, holding a machete in one hand, and stroking his c*ck with the other. She turned and ran, luckily making it back home safe.

text:
A little anecdote; I was in Peru and I had lost my flashlight. I was hiking the trail from the base at Aguacaliente to get to the entrance at Macchu Picchu. I had started just before dawn, but didn‚Äôt realize how dark it‚Äôd be nestled in the Andes. I was using flash photography on my camera and phone to navigate, then I ran into a friendly Aussie guy with a torch-beanie-thing he fashioned, whom I joined until we reached the gate. I related to their random night photos immediately as I remembered all the deleting I had to do afterwards (about 100 or so random night shots in dense woods).

I think these gals were the victims of foul play, but then escaped temporarily in the darkness, navigating with their camera-flashes and calling for help with what little battery they had left. I fear that they were probably apprehended thereafter a final time.

text: The longer I think about this case, the more I feel like the reason we're not piecing it together is because people are treating it like a horse race. It's either a fall, a wild animal, getting lost, or a killer. When there are dozens of scenarios you can think up where it is multiple if not all of the above. Example; they wandered further in/off the path trying to flee someone following them. They ran into a wild animal and got lost trying to get away. One of them fell. The other ended up being found by the initial stalker. Any of those factors could have come in at any given time. A person could have even shown up after they were already dead. There are some sick people in this world. It doesn't have to be just one answer, unfortunately.

text: Image 508 (the last "normal" image) is taken at 19.54 on March 31st - the first emergency call is made at 16.39 the next day. The girls weren't kitted out for an overnight camp as they didn't expect to be doing so. Therefore, apart from the likelihood that whatever happened took place not long after Image 508 was taken, why did it take until late afternoon the next day for the flurry of telephone activity to commence? Perhaps they were unconscious, perhaps they were still mobile at that time and were concentrating on getting out of their predicament. In which case, the telephone activity didn't commence until they were unable to move any further.  Which makes their plight - which likely lasted for a whole week - all the more awful to contemplate.

text: Yes, just discovered "That Chapter" and am catching up on his videos.  Yes, picture #509 had been deleted from one of their phones using a computer. text:
The local family looking after the girls should have prevented them from going. You need a leader type when doing exotic hiking and must stick to the rules. It would be interesting to know how long they intended to walk for. Surely a few hours at most. So at what point did the family expect them back. Example. Ok you start out at what time. Ok, start early and get back at midday. But it seems no real planning occurred.  Bad idea to start walking into the jungle at midday. So the whole Charade is what it is, a charade. Why walk off the path, this makes no sense. You would think that you would only trek as far as you know, to know how to back track easily. Why lose track of time, why allow yourself to get caught at night, in the middle of a jungle. It seems they got lost, which is a 100% guarantee, when you go off track. Then, one fell of that high ravine, caused no doubt by panic, attempting to continue walking, in spite of zero visibility. Sad story. 
 Lastly, did they not know that they wouldn‚Äôt be able to contact anyone. I have a feeling that they actually believed they could. You would think, that theses kind of things would enter the mind of even those with a low IQ. You would also think, just for a moment, that if they met any bad people, then it‚Äôs kind of game over. Again, they seemed to have this naive, we are indestructible attitude. No form of communication, terrible planning and no experience. I feel sorry for them and it‚Äôs right to say, they received no advice.

text: Thanks for this video- is important to keep this tragedy visible. I've watched/read much about their disappearance. There's definitely some unanswered questions, of course (normal for cases where there's no surviving person). There have been some top experts who have reviewed  all available information and none believe there is enough  evidence to suggest foul play. My limited knowledge suggests the simplest explanation: they reached the summit (continental divide) and for reasons we'll never know, decided to explore the trail further, heading down the other side. This area is dense jungle with seldom-used trails making it easy to become disoriented. Most experienced hikers would likely begin backtracking and try to reach an elevated location to hopefully get cell service, but for unknown reasons these ladies continued down towards the opposite side of the divide. Experts will tell you that when a person becomes lost, they become susceptible to a variety of disorienting psychological challenges. It appears (based on forensics of the boot/foot found) that one of them suffered a broken foot, possibly while trying to cross one of the streams via cable bridge. Assuming they stayed together (very likely), this slowed their progress dramatically. The actual scenario towards the end will never be known, but they likely died from starvation (a person with a lean body can starve to death within 3-4 weeks, especially if exerting energy) and/or injuries/infections. Here's my take-away: I've read so many reports similar to this one; a couple things must be said. If you are a hiker going on unfamiliar (to you) terrain, seriously consider always arranging for a guide and/or very good compass, maps, GPS, etc., especially if you are a female. Sexist or not, males generally can survive better under extreme conditions and can also aid others who are mentally/physically disabled so take a trusted guy with you if possible.  My deepest condolences to the families. These two young ladies were clearly very special.

text:
Come on, their deaths was a clear case of foul play. 
i) Lisanne was an avid writer in her diaries and communicated daily with her family. If she felt her time was up or felt she was in mortal danger, she would have recorded something on her camera as a final message to her family, not make some useless shots in the dark. Those shots were probably attempts by the murderer(s) to make as if the women were still alive, false clues. 
ii) Bones - so let's assume they did succumb to their injuries or from starvation and illness, why have there been only a few scattered bone fragments found. What happened to the large bones and their skulls. Could the river have been so weird to wash away these large bones but not those other smaller fragments? Certainly, there are no animals in that jungle that would devour whole skulls? 
iii) The tour guide. It's very convenient isn't it that the tour guide is the one that just happened to be the one to come across the bone fragments. Wasn't this guide alleged to have been in the womens' room at some point during the incident, for what reason? I also recall reading that the guide had some kind of ranch (more like a shack) nearby the trail and this was later DEMOLISHED. 
iv) No mention of the mysteriously deleted photo from the camera? No one in distress is going to take the time to delete a particular photo from their camera. 
v) If it wasn't the tour guide, it certainly is possible the women ran into drug mules..
vi) How were the contents of the backpack and the bag itself dry and intact (see the photos) if they were supposed to be out in the wet and damp jungle? 
...among other questions. 


My guess is, yes the women initially strayed from the trail and got lost hence the attempted calls but then one or more predators who either chanced upon them or were actually following them all along, took the women by force and brought them somewhere, and then days or weeks later disposed of them leaving some scattered bone fragments and some of their belongings - which the inept investigators didn't bother to question.

text:
I know that it can be detrimental to constantly try to instill fear amongst young travelers by warning them that the world is a dark and scary place. That assessment is also, by and large, absolutely wrong. However, it rarely hurts to take extra precautions or to remain partially weary of your new surroundings, at least initially. While traversing terrain you‚Äôre not familiar with, in a country you‚Äôve never been with a language you don‚Äôt fluently speak, it may be best to warm up to it all a little bit before allowing yourself to be fully immersed. 
And I am in NO WAY blaming those young women for the horrors that befell them. The only thing they are guilty of is, perhaps, being too optimistic or trusting. But they did not deserve one iota of what happened to them, but there situation is one that, unfortunately, future young travelers can learn from.

text: When I was young me and a group of maybe 12 people were in an abandoned water park at night and somebody with a flashlight came so we ran into the woods. We got lost for 7 hours. I never been so cut up, sore and distraught. We tried to base a position off of our google maps to avoid calling 911 but we ended up getting split up and everyone‚Äôs phone eventually died except one guy. So we all huddled together, called 911 and gave our compass location. They honked to give us perception of the road. When we got out we had to wait another hour for them to find the that split from us. It was that easy for a group of us to get lost in a forest, I couldn‚Äôt imagine just two people in a jungle with actual predators and mountainous areas... For reference, the area was about 200 acres, if I had to guess. We would‚Äôve gotten out eventually in the daytime we just didn‚Äôt want to ‚Äúrat ourselves out‚Äù being dumb teens. Worth it for the story in my case.

text: I‚Äôm no big fan of the dark myself. I mean, we‚Äôre talking turn-off-the-basement-lights-then-bolt-up-the-steps-before-the-darkness-consumes-me level fear. Because of this, I find it hard to even imagine what those poor young women were going through and, oftentimes, I don‚Äôt even want to try to think about it. They at least had each other initially but I can‚Äôt think that that would even bring much solace considering the situation they were in. It‚Äôs one thing to find yourself a little lost during daylight hours, although it‚Äôs still nerve racking nonetheless, but during the day you at least have some recourse. It‚Äôs infinitely more possible that you might come across a fellow hiker or that you‚Äôd be able to get your bearings in the light of day. Unfortunately it seems like these poor women never got the opportunity. And while in most true crime cases finding the body or remains is usually looked at as positive evidence for the prosecution, in Lisanne and Kris case the finding of their belongings and shortly thereafter their skeletal remains, definitely brought up a lot more questions then it did answers. I pray that their families do get answers soon. I can‚Äôt imagine what they‚Äôre going through.    üíî üíî üíî

text: Thanks, Mike. I now live outside Boquete and I can tell you the footing can be treacherous. Often the weather changes over the course of the day - sunny and mild in the morning, changing to heavy storms or high winds in the afternoon. It's easy to lose your balance. Non-locals are treated very well here (tourism fuels the local economy) but there is poverty all around which is why non-locals can be targets at times for robbery or worse. Two women alone on a quiet trail could be easily subdued. I can vouch that cell phone service in this area is spotty at best unless you are near the town or a tower. One truth about Boquete is you have to plan here to get here. Nobody can reach it by accident. It's attractive to many who come from all over the world for its fantastic climate and international flavor but it is still a remote location with many hazards not encountered often in North America or Europe.

text: I'm really confused by what happened to these girls. If they were murdered, why were they given access to their phones to make emergency phone calls and why were the flags tied around the branches? Why were they kept alive so long? The one girl with a bloody head could have been hit by somebody, so maybe they were trying to run away from that person - who chased them into the jungle. text:
Love your videos, only just seen this. I met the girls when they were in Bocas studying Spanish and they travelled to Boquete with my receptionist. There are many details that are not correct, not your fault.
Police were called in the morning, not at 19.30 and they were notified in Bocas, when the receptionist reported to me that they were missing. The host family did not realise they were not in and had left their breakfasts as normal.
The police immediately went into action both in Bocas and Boquete, checking cctv, interviewing people and taking the pc away from the Spanish school etc.
These poor girls died horribly, but I don't suspect foul play.
The treacherous terrain and deadly rope 'bridges' (lethal) were sufficient to cause terrible injuries.
They had strayed so far off the trail that they were actually heading back across the jungle towards Bocas.
I was and am still here, there is much missing in the story but not generally anything to alter the overall narrative. Rescue services nearly always find missing tourists, sadly not these two. RIP

text: I have seen all the videos about this case that can be found. One thing that is remarcable is the idealization by europeans about the tropics, sine 1492. That is a long history. In that toughts the tropics were seen as paradise without knowing the flora and fauna that had diseases. That idealization by the girls had a price. If you are in Europe and you go in a pine forest in Denmark where i live you soon get lost and begin going in circles. Without a compass and a map (and knowing perfectly how to use them) you are lost. Happily the nordic forests in a flat country are not scarry....As a latinamerican living 35 years in Venezuela i was deep in coastal jungle but my common sense did not got me lost. As an european child  too i got lost in a pine forest near Copenhagen and remembered that very well. Conclusion no. 1 : The girls had NO  exploration experience of ANY KIND. Netherlands is flat.  They had a compass and left it in the hotel. The idealization of the tropics did the other part. text: They were intelligent young women.  Why in the world would they have been walking around at night using the camera flashes as lights??  If you're lost, first rule is stay put, second rule is don't walk around at night, especially in dangerous terrain.  It would have been pitch black out there, and I just don't believe for a second they would have continued walking in those conditions.  Not to mention, they must have known that constantly using the flash would have drained the battery much more quickly.  The smartest thing they could have done as soon as they realized they were lost is to just hunker down, don't go any further, and wait for rescue.  Or for heaven's sake, follow the dog back!  Also the fact that the backpack was found next to water, in perfect dry condition and where it hadn't been the day before.  Plus Mike didn't mention it, but there's a very suspicious "guide" who was involved as well.  Also there's something else.  If you have a camera and/or a phone that takes pictures, it would be very easy to leave information for anyone who might find it.  Just write something in the dirt and take a picture of it.  The whole thing about these obscure "clues" they left, like an arrow that barely looks like an arrow, is ridiculous.  You could easily make a very recognizable arrow out of twigs or stones  if you wanted to.  Why leave something that could be so easily misinterpreted or missed?  Absolutely nothing here makes sense; it's almost like a third party was trying to throw everyone off.  No question foul play was involved in this case.

text:
I always feel so much for the Parents and immediate family and friends where these two are concerned, as apart from their enormous irreplaceable loss they live on with the haunting reality that they can never have answers to the many questions that surround Lissanne and Kris' last days.

In all probability is a case of misadventure. Two more hikers who got wandered off too far and got into trouble wen they realised they were lost, and yet even though I accept that as what most likely happened I also have to confess that there are aspects to some of the evidence that cast doubts for me as well.

There are an awful lot of assumptions made online as to what happened and WHY it happened with these two, but all we can be sure of is that the two set off to the top of the Pianista and made an impressive photo-diary of doing so - it is possible to follow them from the base of the hill right to the top - and beyond as they begin to drop down the other side. Tellingly the photography stops as they reach the first stream, and yet every guide who has taken that route agree that you simply cannot get lost here, nor indeed for some considerable way as the route progresses. So the clear question is why it is Lisanne stops taking photos of Kris at this point...? 
When you review the photography up the hill you can glean quite a bit of information - the two are seen to be sharing carrying the backpack for example, sharing in the photography too. As they reach the top Lisanne has let her hair down while Kris puts hers up. As they drop down the other side it is clear that for at least the next hour it is Lisanne who carries the backpack and is taking the Photos, while Kris is anything up to thirty feet out in front. If you think on that it might suggest some tension at play between the two - Lisanne is the one with some experience at hiking and adventure forays, she probably understands that what they are doing here is rather risky, so does this suggest that she has some doubts and reluctance to be dropping down into this unknown and increasingly difficult territory? If she was the one who let her hair down as they summited the Pianista it suggests that reaching the top was the mission accomplished, that exploring the other side was never the intention. So perhaps Kris being filled with enthusiasm and adrenaline by this point pushes the notion of just taking a quick look over the other side, and keeps going. Lisanne is increasingly not happy as they progress and by the time they reach the stream-crossing her doubts and frustrations over Kris' storming ahead lead to her packing the camera away as she has to concentrate her full energies on keeping up with her partner...

That's all just a theory I stress. The fact that there are no further pictures beyond the stream crossing is one of the significant points to this case, and while I think the above is a credible scenario to explain it I also would like to think that if Kris was aware of her friends concern and unhappiness she would have stopped and agreed to retreat eventually. One has to accept as well that for Lisanne to stop all photography the situation had to be serious - bear in mind that it is still a good two or more hours walk from the stream to where the first calls were made to emergency services. So what could have been going on in those hours?

The other major concern for me is the call logs themselves. The timing and frequency is remarkable as for those first five or six days the calls and signal searches are made at roughly the same hours in the day - why? And why no switch-on at night, when the air would be clearer and a light source much comfort to two girls supposedly lost and sleeping rough in deep forest, in pitch black conditions....?

Yes, on the face of it a case of two girls getting lost in alien territory and paying the price for misadventure, but..... BUT.......
